markdownRemark.html:
I was hired as the first engineer in Vroom’s new NYC HQ to rewrite Vroom.com on a modern tech stack. I rebuilt the website from the ground up as a universal Javascript Single-Page Application using Node.js, React, and Redux. Ultimately I hired, managed, and mentored a team of 5 engineers to work on the codebase, and was promoted to “Engineering Lead”.

Company Overview

Vroom makes over $1b/yr in revenue buying and selling used cars online. Their goal is to make buying a used car as easy as buying a pair of shoes online. Vroom.com is the company’s flagship ecommerce website.

The Problem - Old Website

Unfortunately their website had a lot of issues, which is why I was hired to rewrite it. Here were some of the problems:

  • Extremely slow. Pages would take anywhere from 500ms-5s to load. In the ecommerce world, this directly translates to lost revenue.
  • Website had a lot of bugs
  • Development time was very slow. Deployment was infrequent. The simplest of tasks would take weeks. The stakeholders were fed up.
  • Expensive

Server costs were relatively high.

My Proposal - New Website

I decided to build a Universal Javascript Single-Page App with Node.js, React, and Redux.

Code reviews

Management

We adopted agile/scrum for the sake of scoping out the work and giving a sense of structure. I did weekly 1-on-1 meetings with each member of my team to ensure no one was blocked and any concerns would be voiced.

I’m a strong believer in empowering individuals, and am very much against micromanagement as I believe it is patronizing, unproductive, and reduces morale. If a team member isn’t pulling his or her weight, he/she is generally aware. We’ll have a talk to understand what’s going on and to see if things can be improved. If things don’t turn around after that, well then that doesn’t leave many other options…

In any case, I prefer being direct and understanding. One should never be passive aggressive - it just makes everyone miserable (in general, not just at work).

Feedback

The

Promotion to Lead Engineer.

Conclusion

I’m so grateful to have been given this opportunity. Specifically, I have to thank John Rodkey for believing in me. And of course I have to thank the team who brought this to life, and continue to carry it on after I’ve left.

The new site is blazing fast and light years ahead of the old one. Developing on the site is so easy, it’s “boring” (in a good way :P). To be honest, I’d never seen an ecommerce site as a single-page app, but I’m convinced the entire web will eventually move to single-page apps as the technology gets easier to develop. You just can’t beat the page speed performance of not having page refreshes.
